questions.text: A newborn develops refusal to feed by day 2, vomiting with breastfeeding, and diarrhoea by day 3. By day 5, he develops jaundice, hepatomegaly, and bilateral cataracts. Urine tests positive for reducing sugars, and blood glucose is very low. On eye examination, oil-drop cataracts are noted. Which of the following sugar alcohols is responsible for the cataract formation in this newborn?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture is suggestive of classic galactosemia, most often caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT).

  • Galactose, unable to be properly metabolised, accumulates.
  • It is reduced by aldose reductase to galactitol (also called dulcitol).
  • Dulcitol accumulates in the lens, drawing in water and leading to osmotic cataract formation, especially the classic oil-drop cataract seen in galactosemia.

Other associated findings:

  • Hepatomegaly, jaundice, due to the toxic buildup of galactose-1-phosphate in the liver.
  • Hypoglycemia, due to liver dysfunction.
  • Positive urinary reducing sugars, due to galactose in the urine.

Explanation of other options:

Ribitol (Option A): A sugar alcohol derived from ribose; not implicated in galactosemia.

Sorbitol (Option C): Formed from glucose in diabetes; involved in diabetic cataracts, not in galactosemia.

Xylitol (Option D): A sugar alcohol used as a sweetener; not produced in galactose metabolism.

questions.text: Active transport is not required for the absorption of which of the following molecules?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fructose is absorbed in the small intestine by facilitated diffusion, not active transport.
  • It uses a Na+-independent transporter called GLUT5, which allows fructose to move down its concentration gradient into enterocytes without the use of ATP or sodium gradients.
  • After entering the enterocyte, GLUT2 helps transport fructose into the bloodstream.

Explanation of other options:

Glucose (Option A): Glucose absorption occurs via SGLT1, a sodium-dependent secondary active transporter. It couples glucose uptake with Na+ ions using the Na+/K+ ATPase pump to maintain the gradient. Requires active transport.

Galactose (Option B): Like glucose, galactose is absorbed through SGLT1, which is also Na+-dependent. It uses secondary active transport to enter enterocytes against its concentration gradient. Requires active transport.

Sucrose (Option D): Sucrose is a disaccharide and cannot be absorbed directly. It must first be broken down by sucrase into glucose and fructose. Thus, sucrose itself is not absorbed, and its breakdown products do use transporters, some of which involve active mechanisms.

questions.text: In which of the following steps is ATP released?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The conversion of Phosphoenol pyruvate to pyruvate is catalysed by the enzyme pyruvate kinase in glycolysis.
  • It is an example of substrate-level phosphorylation, where a high-energy phosphate bond from phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) is transferred to ADP, forming ATP and pyruvate.
  • This reaction is irreversible and a key regulatory step in glycolysis.

Explanation of other options:

Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate (Option B): This step is catalyzed by glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. It requires NAD+ and inorganic phosphate (Pi) but does not generate ATP at this point. It's an energy-requiring step that stores energy for a subsequent ATP-generating step.

Fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate (Option C): This is a rate-limiting and committed step of glycolysis catalysed by phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1). It actually uses ATP to phosphorylate F6P. No ATP is produced; ATP is consumed.

Glucose to glucose-6-phosphate (Option D): Catalysed by hexokinase (or glucokinase in the liver). This step also consumes ATP to phosphorylate glucose. Again, no ATP is produced; it is used.

choices.text: Absorption of fructose into intestinal epithelial cells is by facilitated transport and thus does not require energy
Metabolism of fructose generates more energy than glucose
Some fructose is absorbed in the mouth, hence it is the fastest way to give energy
The presence of fructose inhibits the reabsorption of glucose, which is then more readily available for muscle activity

questions.text: An advertisement promotes energy bars containing fructose as an ideal food to take on extreme mountain-climbing expeditions. Which of the following statements concerning fructose absorption is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fructose is absorbed passively via facilitated diffusion using the GLUT5 transporter on the apical membrane of enterocytes.
  • It does not require ATP or a sodium gradient, unlike glucose and galactose, which use SGLT1 (sodium-dependent).
  • Fructose then exits the enterocyte into the blood via GLUT2 on the basolateral membrane.

Explanation of other options:

Metabolism of fructose generates more energy than glucose (Option B): Incorrect. Fructose and glucose both yield similar amounts of ATP when metabolised. Fructose bypasses phosphofructokinase (PFK-1), leading to less regulation but not more energy.

Some fructose is absorbed in the mouth; hence, it is the fastest way to give energy (Option C): Incorrect. Unlike glucose, fructose is not absorbed in the oral cavity. It must be digested and absorbed in the small intestine.

The presence of fructose inhibits the reabsorption of glucose, which is then more readily available for muscle activity (Option D): Incorrect and biochemically inaccurate. Fructose does not inhibit glucose absorption or reabsorption. Both can be absorbed simultaneously through independent transporters.

questions.text: All of the following occur during the resting state except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During fasting, the blood glucose level drops, which leads to:

  • ↑ Glucagon secretion (from pancreatic alpha cells)
  • Glucagon → Activates adenylate cyclase → ↑ cAMP → Activates Protein Kinase A (PKA)
  • PKA phosphorylates the bifunctional enzyme (PFK-2/FBPase-2), resulting in:
    • ↓ PFK-2 activity (which normally produces Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate)
    • ↑ FBPase-2 activity (which breaks down Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate)

Net result: ↓ Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate

This decrease:

  • Inhibits glycolysis (less activation of PFK-1)
  • Stimulates gluconeogenesis (less inhibition of fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase)

Explanation of other options:

Inhibition of PFK-II (Option A): Correct: Glucagon → PKA phosphorylates PFK-2 → Inhibited.

Activation of Fructose 2,6-Bisphosphatase (Option B): Correct: The same phosphorylation activates the FBPase-2 part of the bifunctional enzyme.

Increase in glucagon (Option C): Correct: Glucagon increases in response to hypoglycemia during fasting.

Key takeaways:

Fructose 2,6-bisphosphate increases only in the fed state, promoting glycolysis.

During fasting, its levels decrease, shifting metabolism toward gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: The enzyme responsible for the complete oxidation of glucose to CO2 and water is located in the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The complete oxidation of glucose involves multiple steps:

  1. Glycolysis occurs in the cytosol, producing pyruvate.
  2. Pyruvate oxidation to acetyl-CoA occurs in the mitochondrial matrix.
  3. Citric Acid Cycle (Krebs Cycle) - also in the mitochondrial matrix, fully oxidises acetyl-CoA to CO2.
  4. Electron Transport Chain and Oxidative Phosphorylation - located on the inner mitochondrial membrane, converts NADH/FADH2 into ATP and forms H2O by reducing O2.

Thus, mitochondria are the key site for the complete oxidation of glucose to CO2 and water.

Explanation of other options:

Cytosol (Option A): Site of glycolysis only, not full oxidation. Pyruvate remains incompletely oxidized here.

Lysosomes (Option C): Involved in the degradation of macromolecules, not glucose metabolism.

Endoplasmic reticulum (Option D): Involved in protein and lipid synthesis, not glucose oxidation.

Explanation:

Pyruvate kinase catalyzes the final step of glycolysis, where the high-energy phosphate from phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) is directly transferred to ADP to form ATP and pyruvate. This is a classic example of substrate-level phosphorylation, because ATP is generated directly from a phosphorylated metabolic intermediate without involvement of the electron-transport chain.

Explanation of other options:

Phosphofructokinase (Option B):

  • Catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate.
  • Consumes ATP (adding a phosphate), rather than producing it.

Hexokinase (Option C):

  • Catalyzes the first step of glycolysis: glucose → glucose-6-phosphate.
  • Also uses ATP to phosphorylate glucose; does not generate ATP.

ATP Synthase (Option D):

  • Generates ATP by oxidative phosphorylation in the mitochondria, using the proton-motive force across the inner membrane.
  • This is not substrate-level phosphorylation, but rather chemiosmotic phosphorylation via the electron-transport chain.

Key Takeaways:

  • Substrate-level phosphorylation occurs when a phosphorylated intermediate directly donates its phosphate to ADP (e.g., via pyruvate kinase or phosphoglycerate kinase).
  • Oxidative phosphorylation (via ATP synthase) relies on the electron-transport chain and a proton gradient.

questions.text: Acetyl-CoA can be converted into all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acetyl-CoA cannot be converted back into glucose in humans because:

  • The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDH) reaction (which converts pyruvate → acetyl-CoA) is irreversible.
  • Once carbons enter the TCA cycle as Acetyl-CoA, they are lost as CO2, not available for gluconeogenesis.
  • Net gain of glucose from Acetyl CoA is not possible, unlike from certain amino acids or lactate.

Thus, while Acetyl CoA is a central metabolic intermediate, it is not glucogenic.

Explanation of other options:

Fatty acids (Option B): Acetyl-CoA is a precursor for fatty acid synthesis via malonyl-CoA.

Cholesterol (Option C): Cholesterol is synthesised from multiple acetyl-CoA units via the mevalonate pathway.

Ketone bodies(Option D): In liver mitochondria, Acetyl CoA is converted to acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone, especially during fasting/starvation.

questions.text: A breastfed infant comes with frequent vomiting and loss of weight. After several days, he developed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and bilateral cataracts. What is the possible diagnosis of this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture points towards galactosemia:

  • The infant is breastfed, which means they are consuming lactose (broken down into glucose and galactose).
  • In classic galactosemia (due to GALT deficiency), the body cannot metabolize galactose properly.
  • This leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol.
  • Galactitol accumulates in the lens, causing bilateral cataracts (a hallmark sign).
  • Additional findings like vomiting, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive are typical.

Explanation of other options:

Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus (Type 1 DM) (Option A):

  • Typically presents after infancy (usually after age 5).
  • Features polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, but not cataracts, hepatomegaly, or jaundice in this context.

Gaucher's Disease (Option B):

  • A lysosomal storage disorder causing hepatosplenomegaly, bone crises, and anemia.
  • No association with cataracts or acute symptoms triggered by milk.

Hereditary Fructose Intolerance (HFI) (Option C):

  • Caused by aldolase B deficiency.
  • Symptoms are triggered by fructose intake, not lactose.
  • Presents after weaning (when fructose is introduced).
  • No cataracts are seen in HFI.

questions.text: All of the following metabolites are seen in the HMP Shunt except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glycerol-3-phosphate is not part of the HMP shunt.

It is involved in lipid metabolism and glycerol phosphate shuttle, not in the pentose phosphate pathway.

Metabolites in HMP Shunt Pathway:

  • Glucose-6-phosphate
  • 6-Phosphogluconate
  • Ribulose-5-Phosphate
  • Xylulose-5-Phosphate (Option D ruled out)
  • Ribose-5-Phosphate
  • Glyceraldehyde-3-Phosphate (Option C ruled out)
  • Sedoheptulose-7-Phosphate (Option B ruled out)
  • Fructose-6-phosphate
  • Erythrose 4 Phosphate
